title: Do phone cameras add pounds in pictures? - Quora

response.answer_text: It used to be said “cameras add 10 lb” and that was any camera. OK it doesn’t add weight, what it adds is width. How? Because you are looking at a 3D body in 2D representation. Imagine looking at a cylinder. In 3D you see there is part of the cylinder closer to you then it curves away to its diameter, further away from you. You “know” its a cylinder and you get a sense of width and depth. In 2D, you only see the full diameter without the sense of curving away. With lighting, you can add or subtract to the sense of width. Where the lighting is even, like for a TV newsreader, the width is ‘flattened out” and accentuated. With single source side or angle light you see the shape and textures better. Then, phone cameras tend to have wide angle lens as default, giving a wider field of view. They distort the perspective so things appear wider than in real life, what we call a barrel effect. Something like | | in real life will look like ( ) with a wide angle lens.

They can and when they do the effect is generally greater than with other cameras. Using other cameras (like a dSLR) you can select a lens that is a bit longer than “normal”. This tends to flatten the view and record a pleasing image. Phone cameras tend to have very wide lenses (records a broad view at limited distances). Wide lenses exaggerate depth and if not used carefully can substantially distort an image, especially toward the image edges. Images produced under these conditions are generally less pleasing.

The prior answers are good. I would add that because they are so often used for selfies, phone cameras have wide angle lenses so they can be held at arm's length and still get everything in. Wide angle lenses tend to exaggerate perspective at close ranges, making noses look bigger and people look heavier. For that reason, professionals use telephoto lenses for portraits and model shoots; teles tend to flatten perspective, making people look thinner.

Being overly critical of yourself adds pounds to your pictures otherwise the perspective of a phone camera lense is not so drastic that it would falsely add pounds to your bodies appearance. I could understand wondering about using a fish eye lens and distortion from reality but a standard lense wouldn’t in my view have this effect.

Especially if you print them all. My present cellphone carries some six thousand pictures, which if printed would amount to some five thousand Euros, that is, more than 3 thousand Pounds. They add……..
